data.title: 2016 Edmonton Oilers prospects series: Which longshot has the best chance at an NHL career?
data.meta_description: The Cult of Hockey’s summer prospect coverage kicks off today, with a look at the longshot players at the bottom of the Edmonton Oilers’ prospect list.
data.text:
Article content

The Cult of Hockey’s summer prospect coverage kicks off today, with a look at the longshot players at the bottom of the Edmonton Oilers’ prospect list.

This series is a long-running feature of this site; this will be the sixth summer where we have provided comprehensive profiles of the majority of prospects in the system.

We apologize, but this video has failed to load.

Try refreshing your browser, or

tap here to see other videos from our team.

2016 Edmonton Oilers prospects series: Which longshot has the best chance at an NHL career? Back to video

As in previous years, our criteria for inclusion is that a player must be Oilers’ property (so, for example, AHL signing Josh Currie would not count) and eligible for the Calder Trophy. The Calder criteria means that some prospects who are considered on other lists will be discounted due games played (Griffin Reinhart, for example, is no longer eligible). Age is also a factor most years, though this summer there aren’t any players under contract who are under the games played minimum but over the age threshold.

Article content

Using that criteria, David Staples, Bruce McCurdy and I each voted on the pool of 36 players who qualified for inclusion. The top 25 players on our list will each get their own write-ups, but in this introductory post we’ll take a quick look at the players below that threshold. They are as follow:

26. RW Greg Chase (2015 rank: No. 7 overall). A year ago, the expectation was that Chase would establish himself as an AHL regular in his rookie year, with colleague McCurdy setting 60-odd games and 20-ish points as a line in the sand. Chase scored at almost exactly that pace but appeared in only 19 games, spending the bulk of the season in the ECHL. Expectations for 2016-17: 30 points and a full season in the AHL.

27. G Dylan Wells (N/A; drafted 123rd overall in 2016). Wells has NHL size, with a 6’2” frame, but his save percentage trended the wrong way in the OHL last year, falling down to 0.871. One would assume that he’s at least five years away from challenging for NHL employment even if everything goes exceedingly well. Expectations: At least 40 games and an improved save percentage.

Article content

Story continues below

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

28. LW Graham McPhee (N/A; drafted 149th overall in 2016). The son of new Las Vegas general manager George McPhee, Graham McPhee spent last year in the U.S. national development program, and is going to go the college route. He’s undersized but competitive, and projects as a bottom-six forward. Expectations: Win a regular job at the college level.

29. LW Mitch Moroz (2015 rank: No. 23 overall). A year ago, I suggested that Moroz needed to at least double the nine points he’d managed as a rookie pro if he wanted to stay in the Oilers plans. Instead he gained one point, climbing to 10 in an injury-shortened 40 game season. He’s entering the final year of his entry-level contract and needs a breakout performance if he wants another NHL deal. Expectations for 2016-17: At least 25 points over a healthy campaign.

30. RW Tyler Vesel (2015 rank: No. 26 overall). Vesel is an undersized offensive forward, and the offence didn’t develop last season. He went from eight goals and 23 points as a 20-year-old college freshman to six goals and 18 points as a sophomore. He has time but needs to show more scoring over the next two years to get an entry-level deal. Expectations for 2016-17: 30 points would be a good step forward.

Advertisement 4

Story continues below

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

31. LW Braden Christoffer (N/A; signed with Bakersfield in May 2015). Christoffer so impressed in training camp that the Oilers gave the Sherwood Park native an entry-level contract. Unfortunately, he didn’t make the most of things in his first year with the team, scoring just five points in 33 AHL games and earning a long (and largely successful) stint in the ECHL. Expectations for 2016-17: Spend the entire year in the AHL.

32. LW Evan Campbell (2015 rank: No. 27 overall). After a breakthrough performance at the college level in which Campbell came close to the point-per-game mark, 2015-16 represented a massive disappointment. He fell to 11th in team scoring, with his both his goal and assist totals cut in half. As a result, rather than climbing into the top-25, he fell five spots in our rankings. The only good news for Campbell is that Edmonton doesn’t make its signing decision until the end of next season. Expectations for 2016-17: Score at a point-per-game pace.

33. RD Vincent Desharnais (N/A; drafted 183rd overall in 2016). An overage selection who went unselected in 2014 and 2015, Desharnais has two significant items in his favour: He’s a right shot and he’s 6’6”. He only played 19 games for Providence College last season, and the year before scored only five points in 54 BCHL games. Expectations for 2016-17: Play a full season at the college level.

Advertisement 5

Story continues below

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

34. LW Aidan Muir (2015 rank: No. 29 overall). Muir was projectable, because what NHL team doesn’t want a 6’4” winger that can skate? The problem is that there’s no sign yet that he can score. We were hoping to see 0.5 points/game as a college freshman, but as a sophomore last year he couldn’t manage even half that and scored only two goals all season. Expectations for 2016-17: Can he crack 0.5 points/game in his third try?

35. G Miroslav Svoboda (2015 rank: No. 31 overall). Svoboda is improving, just not quickly enough. He played 29 games in the second-tier Czech league last season, and managed a 0.924 save percentage for HC Sumperk. That he’s now 21 years old and appears bound for another season outside of the Czech Republic’s top league is really not a great sign, though. Expectations for 2016-17: Push his way out of the second tier.

36. G Zach Nagelvoort (2015 rank: No. 30 overall). Nagelvoort has played three seasons at the University of Michigan now. His games played over those seasons were 24, 22 and 11 respectively. His save percentage over the same span went from 0.929 to 0.906 to 0.893. He’s in freefall as a prospect and has clearly been passed by the undrafted Steven Racine. Expectations for 2016-17: If he doesn’t excel in the starting role, it’s hard to imagine he’s signed to an entry-level deal.

That’s 11 different players. The question now is which of them has the best shot at an NHL career?

Advertisement 6

Story continues below

Article content

I opted for Chase, ranking him well inside the top 25. For the second year in a row, colleagues Staples and McCurdy were in lockstep, with each opting for Wells. We’ll leave it to our readers to make up their own minds:
